  • words on "when to use classes"
  • september 8, 2014

    • Classes are daunting. With possibly hundreds of lines of code, it can be tough to wrap your head around them. Luckily, it's not that hard to figure them out.

    What are classes?

    • 1. You can think of classes as a BIG method. With many other methods inside of it. (Really, they're objects that knows and does things)
    • 2. Classes also have certain attributes, or properties, or things about them that make them them! You anc usually list these in the initialize method (explained later).
      class Puppies #a big method... def initialize(color, tail_length) ... end def bark #with a "mini" method puts "RAWR" end end

    Here, we have can see that this Dog has a mini method that allows dog's to bark. It also holds a collection of different attributes, like the dog's color (red, white, blue) and tail length (short, medium, long).

    Why use classes?

    • 1. Sometimes, you want to create more than one dog. Classes are a way of organizing objects with similar attributes and methods, so you don't have to rewrite all the code over again.
      • dog_1 = Puppies.new("blue", "short") dog_2 = Puppies.new("red", "long")

      And, there we go. We have two class objects with the same general attributes and bark method. They're just a little different -- color-wise and tail-wise -- but otherwise they're just as loveable.

    How to use classes

    1. 1. Initialize some attributes
      2. class Puppies def initialize(color, tail_length) @color = color @tail_length = tail_length end end

      By storing the color of the dog (like "blue"), into the @color variable. The dog object now knows something about itself. Initializing helps the dog know things.

    2. 2. Make some instance methods to help the class do things
      3. class Puppies ... def bark puts "RAWR" + " I'm a dog dammit." end end dog_1 = Puppies.new("blue", "short") dog_1.bark ## "RAWR I'm a dog dammit."
    3. 3. Access instance variables with the proper scope.
      4. class Puppies ... def bark puts "RAWR" + " I'm a #{@color} dog dammit." @noise = "loud" end #the following won't work def wrong_sleep puts "I'm tired of making such " + @noise + " noise." end #so you have to write def correct_sleep puts "I'm going to sleep and dream of #{@color}." end end dog_1.bark dog_1.correct_sleep ## "RAWR I'm a blue dog dammit." ## "I'm going to sleep and dream of blue."

      Here, bark and correct_sleep properly dispalys the color of the dog, along with the string. However, wrong_sleep doesn't work. Why? Scoping

      Bark and correct_sleep can access the @color blue because the Puppies' initialize class basically sets a default instance variables that any method can access. However, #wrong_sleep can't access the @noise because @noise is only available/alive/exists within the bark method. That said, if you call #bark first -- @noise will equal "loud" -- and you can correctly call #wrong_sleep.
